Line 8: Line 8:
==April 6: day of the strike==
==April 6: day of the strike==
â
[[File:Security forces cairo.jpg|thumb|left|Security forces in Cairo beating protesters in 2008]]
+
[[File:Security forces cairo.jpg|thumb|Security forces in Cairo beating protesters in 2008]]
The strike at Mahalla was to have begun at 7 a.m. but plain clothes security personnel and police infiltrated the factory and allegedly intimidated workers from striking.<ref>[http://www.dailystaregypt.com/article.aspx?ArticleID=12933 Sarah Carr, "Two allegedly killed during violent clashes in Mahalla," ''Daily News Egypt,'' 6 April 2008.]</ref> Hundreds of plainclothes security men took control of the Mahalla textile factories before work began, seizing workers and forcing them to work. At the end of the day, police escorts led small groups of workers out of the factories in an attempt to discourage mass protests.<ref name="Nouri">[http://africa.reuters.com/world/news/usnL06488125.html Nasser Nouri, "Clashes in Nile Delta After Strike Aborted," ''Reuters,'' 6 April 2008.]</ref> This led some in the press to call the strike a failure and many left the region (about an hour outside Cairo) before any violence started.<ref>[http://www.dailystaregypt.com/article.aspx?ArticleID=12918 Rania Al Malky, "Reflections: Bread or freedom?", ''Daily News Egypt,'' 6 April 2008.]</ref>. Two people, including a 15-year-old-boy, were killed by Egyptian police, who used tear gas, rubber bullets, and live ammunition against the striking workers and other protesters.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/low/middle_east/7332929.stm Clashes in Egypt strike stand-off] [[BBC News]], 7 April 2008; [http://africa.reuters.com/wire/news/usnL11177911.html "Egypt Police Hold Academics on Way to Troubled Town," ''Reuters,'' April 11, 2008]; [http://www.voanews.com/english/2008-04-11-voa56.cfm Challiss McDonough, "Egypt Security Forces Block Activists, Doctors from Reaching Strike Town," ''Voice of America,'' 11 April 2008]; [http://www.afriquenligne.fr/news/africa-news/tension-remains-high-in-egypt-over-clashes,-election-200804091563.html "Tension Remains High in Egypt Over Clashes, Election," ''Panapress,'' 9 April 2008]; [http://hrw.org/english/docs/2008/04/11/egypt18517_txt.htm "Egypt: Investigate Police Use of Force at Protests," press release, ''Human Rights Watch,'' April 11, 2008]; [http://www.allheadlinenews.com/articles/7010578245 "Boy Dies In Clashes In Northern Egyptian Town," ''All Headline News,'' April 8, 2008]; [http://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSL08810639 Wael Gamal, "Police Shoot Boy Dead in Troubled Nile Delta Town," ''Retuers,'' 8 April 2008]; [http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/04/08/africa/ME-GEN-Egypt-Protest-Death.php "Egyptian Boy Dies From Wounds Sustained in Mahalla Food Riots," ''Associated Press,'' April 8, 2008].</ref>. Several leaders of opposition parties have been detained, including the [[Kifaya]] coordinator Mohamed el-Ashqar, Freedom Commission Rapporteur of the Labor Party Mohamed Abdel Kodous, prominent activist and Kifaya member Magdy Qarqar, and blogger Sharkawy<ref>[http://sharkawy.wordpress.com/ Sharkawy Web site.]</ref> (who was sodomized and tortured by Egyptian police in 2006),<ref>[http://www.slate.com/id/2166146 Wael Abbas, "Big Brothers: In Egypt, Blogging Can Get You ArrestedâOr Worse," ''Slate,'' May 14, 2007.]</ref> and others.<ref>[http://africa.reuters.com/top/news/usnBAN024488.html Will Rasmussen, "Egypt Detains Opposition Figure After Strike Attempt," ''Reuters,'' 10 April 2008.]</ref>
The strike at Mahalla was to have begun at 7 a.m. but plain clothes security personnel and police infiltrated the factory and allegedly intimidated workers from striking.<ref>[http://www.dailystaregypt.com/article.aspx?ArticleID=12933 Sarah Carr, "Two allegedly killed during violent clashes in Mahalla," ''Daily News Egypt,'' 6 April 2008.]</ref> Hundreds of plainclothes security men took control of the Mahalla textile factories before work began, seizing workers and forcing them to work. At the end of the day, police escorts led small groups of workers out of the factories in an attempt to discourage mass protests.<ref name="Nouri">[http://africa.reuters.com/world/news/usnL06488125.html Nasser Nouri, "Clashes in Nile Delta After Strike Aborted," ''Reuters,'' 6 April 2008.]</ref> This led some in the press to call the strike a failure and many left the region (about an hour outside Cairo) before any violence started.<ref>[http://www.dailystaregypt.com/article.aspx?ArticleID=12918 Rania Al Malky, "Reflections: Bread or freedom?", ''Daily News Egypt,'' 6 April 2008.]</ref>. Two people, including a 15-year-old-boy, were killed by Egyptian police, who used tear gas, rubber bullets, and live ammunition against the striking workers and other protesters.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/low/middle_east/7332929.stm Clashes in Egypt strike stand-off] [[BBC News]], 7 April 2008; [http://africa.reuters.com/wire/news/usnL11177911.html "Egypt Police Hold Academics on Way to Troubled Town," ''Reuters,'' April 11, 2008]; [http://www.voanews.com/english/2008-04-11-voa56.cfm Challiss McDonough, "Egypt Security Forces Block Activists, Doctors from Reaching Strike Town," ''Voice of America,'' 11 April 2008]; [http://www.afriquenligne.fr/news/africa-news/tension-remains-high-in-egypt-over-clashes,-election-200804091563.html "Tension Remains High in Egypt Over Clashes, Election," ''Panapress,'' 9 April 2008]; [http://hrw.org/english/docs/2008/04/11/egypt18517_txt.htm "Egypt: Investigate Police Use of Force at Protests," press release, ''Human Rights Watch,'' April 11, 2008]; [http://www.allheadlinenews.com/articles/7010578245 "Boy Dies In Clashes In Northern Egyptian Town," ''All Headline News,'' April 8, 2008]; [http://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSL08810639 Wael Gamal, "Police Shoot Boy Dead in Troubled Nile Delta Town," ''Retuers,'' 8 April 2008]; [http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/04/08/africa/ME-GEN-Egypt-Protest-Death.php "Egyptian Boy Dies From Wounds Sustained in Mahalla Food Riots," ''Associated Press,'' April 8, 2008].</ref>. Several leaders of opposition parties have been detained, including the [[Kifaya]] coordinator Mohamed el-Ashqar, Freedom Commission Rapporteur of the Labor Party Mohamed Abdel Kodous, prominent activist and Kifaya member Magdy Qarqar, and blogger Sharkawy<ref>[http://sharkawy.wordpress.com/ Sharkawy Web site.]</ref> (who was sodomized and tortured by Egyptian police in 2006),<ref>[http://www.slate.com/id/2166146 Wael Abbas, "Big Brothers: In Egypt, Blogging Can Get You ArrestedâOr Worse," ''Slate,'' May 14, 2007.]</ref> and others.<ref>[http://africa.reuters.com/top/news/usnBAN024488.html Will Rasmussen, "Egypt Detains Opposition Figure After Strike Attempt," ''Reuters,'' 10 April 2008.]</ref>
